Virtual reality as a communication process

  • Daniele Marini1,
  • Raffaella Folgieri2,
  • Davide Gadia1 &
  • Alessandro Rizzi1 

Virtual Reality volume 16, pages233–241(2012)Cite this article

  • 1621 Accesses

  • 9 Citations

  • 1 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

In this work, we consider immersive Virtual Reality (VR) as a communication process between humans, mediated by computer systems, which uses interaction, visualization, and other sensory stimuli to convey information. From this viewpoint, it is relevant to understand how VR can solve a given communication problem, what is therefore the expressive power of VR system, i.e., its ability in establishing the communication, what are the guidelines to design an effective system, and what are the more relevant models of VR applications. Firstly, we try to clarify the notion of reality in Virtual Reality systems and conclude that reality is not an intrinsic characteristic of VR, rather the result of a conventional way of coding information. The purpose of coding is to lead the observer to the conclusion that the VR set is what is called in italian as verisimile (from Latin veri similis), i.e., “similar-to-the-real-thing”. So the creation of an effective VR application is an artifice or an illusion. But in order to avoid an over-reliance on the creativity of the VR designer, we intend to identify a solid ground on which different kinds of VR solutions can be considered in terms of their ability to solve the desired communication objective. To this aim, we will rely on methods derived from rhetoric to semiotics.

Introduction

In research done by M. Fagiolo dell’Arco (Fagiolo dell’Arco 1997), there is a discussion of some of the elements that characterize one of the most interesting expressions in Baroque art, specifically found in Roma during 17th century. Besides famous works of architecture by Bernini or Borromini, like Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza or Piazza Navona, Fagiolo explores the characters of the scenic setting and the metamorphosis of the scenic elements, specifically build for a banquet, a religious or civil celebration, a coronation or a wedding. Spectacular automata, theatrical machinery, fireworks, and architectural settings were used to create performances for large public events, to entertain and enjoy laypeople as well as aristocrats and cultured people. In the twenty-first century, VR technology allows us to create similar effects. While the Baroque festivities were an instrument to celebrate the power of Popes and aristocrats, VR is popular and democratic. But there remains a common element, which is rooted, in essential anthropological characteristic: the need for enjoyment and celebration, the need for horrific and marvelous, and the desire for drama and fantasy. But when the computer is switched off, everything disappears as in the grand finale of a firework display, leaving only the memory of the emotions.

The instrument that is the foundation of such an emotional effect is rhetoric, an art and science to assist in the construction of arguments and to build and strengthen a discourse. It is in Baroque art and in particular in the Baroque feast, which we find the most relevant example of a specific kind of rhetoric: visual rhetoric, with all its basic figures, like the metaphor, the hyperbole, the oxymoron, and the allegory. The extended use of such rhetorical figures, which can be recognized in the architectural works, for example, by Gian Lorenzo Bernini (1598–1680), demonstrates that rhetoric is not only an art applied to speech, but also to theater and visual communication. For example, the Baldacchino in S. Peter’s Cathedral in Roma is considered as a hyperbole, obtained by the use of the gigantic shape and the richness of decoration. An example of a metaphor is the Fontana delle Api (Fountain of the Bees), where the bees pour out honey that then becomes water. Contemporary movies are also examples of visual rhetoric, which combines partly the narrative structure of the script and largely the use of visual effects that highlight and reinforce the story to the audience.

Assuming this historical perspective, we intend to analyze the technology of Virtual Reality from a viewpoint that is not focused on the techniques, but instead on the way techniques are selected, manipulated, and adapted to attain a specific purpose: to assist in the art of persuasion and simulation, through the use of splendid and marvelous effects. These effects are of paramount importance to fulfill the objectives: to assist the participant in fully experiencing VR, cinema or a social feast, as a real and fully immersive event.

In Sect. 2, we introduce the context and the background of the proposed approach and outline our viewpoint. In Sect. 3, we discuss the notion of realism and propose the concept of believable that better represents the cultural, historical, and social nature of realism. Being believable means that a VR solution is verisimile, i.e., similar to the real thing or situation. We will present an overview of different ideas of realism in visual arts and a critique on translating the concept in VR context. We consider the realism as a result of a rhetoric choice, being rhetoric the basis of any communication.

In Sect. 4, we introduce our view of VR as a communication process and how a semiotic approach can clarify its structure, considering different abstraction levels: syntactic, semantics, and lastly pragmatics levels. In order to clarify our approach, we describe a case study that demonstrates how the principles of communication and semiotics are necessary to design the best VR solution to model an interactive simulation.

In Sect. 5, we focus on human–VR interaction, which is a specific characteristic of VR-based communication and strongly influences the emotional effects of the communication process to the users.

In Sect. 6, we describe in depth the pragmatic level, as the key to explore the relationship between signs and their meaning in relationship to values and social culture.

Context and background

We consider Virtual Reality (VR) applications used in immersive VR systems, where the sensation of presence is conveyed by minimizing the contact of the user with the external real world, thus differentiating from web-based VR application that are normally manipulated through a mouse and the PC display. The common definition of immersivity describes it as the degree to which a VR system stimulates the sensory system without interference from external environment. In case of visual sensory system it depends, among other factors, on the field of view, so particularly interesting are VR installations that fill the observer’s field of view, by means of large screens, rooms, or head-mounted displays. Immersivity can also be increased by reducing or even excluding external stimuli and increasing virtual sensory stimuli. It is relevant, for our purpose, to also introduce the definition of presence that is the psychological impression of being there (Slater 2003). Presence and immersivity can also be increased with a high degree of visual realism that can be reached with specific computer graphics solutions.

Discussing the notion of presence and immersivity, Bowman and MacMahan (Bowman 2007) consider the most successful areas of VR application, and they attempt to identify which factors play the most important role to obtain effective VR and to understand the efficacy of immersivity and presence. They recall that the most relevant success stories of immersive VR are in the application fields of entertainment, training (flight or driving simulators, military training), or psychological studies and clinical treatment of phobias. Each field requires its own level of immersivity that can vary greatly; the questions remain open: which components of immersion result in benefits and whether a lower level of immersion can yield the same benefits. Their research is confined to the evaluation of technical means to increase or decrease immersivity and presence.

We prefer to change radically the viewpoint by first discussing the notion of physical fidelity and psychological fidelity of a VR application that has been proposed as the guideline to design VR applications (Alexander et al. 2005). A particular application we intend to consider is training in industrial processes, where a weak understanding of the effects induced by VR in the trainee can negatively affect the efficacy of training. In such cases, it is normally assumed that users sense the virtual experience as real, both physically and psychologically. We raise the objection that the notion of fidelity, in particular psychological fidelity, is not well defined. We recall that VR uses the term reality to convey the notion that virtual scenarios are a kind of reality. It should, therefore, be preferable to use the notions of physical or psychological reality instead. But this concept is still unclear. Since virtual interactive scenarios aim at conveying the notion that what we see—and with which we interact—is the real thing, we prefer to stress the notion that the goal of VR is to make the experience believable. In Italian, we use the word verisimile that means “similar to the true, genuine, actual thing”; therefore, in our view, the aim of VR is to induce the VR user to think that what he or she sees and manipulates leads them to conclude that it is the real thing.Footnote 1 To ensure that a VR simulation is believable, it is not always necessary to use realism, and in many cases, symbolic solutions can be even more effective. The choice of symbols, metaphors, and allegories, in verbal communication, is the subject of rhetoric. So, we need VR rhetoric and specifically visual rhetoric as a guide to design effective applications.

Real and believable

The concept of realism in the context of visual arts has maintained a long history in Western culture, and in the last century, this has encompassed new areas such as cinema. A relevant discussion is in (Goodman 1968), to which we refer briefly. First, we must start from the observation that a representation is a symbol of an object, it denotes the object. To this aim, there is no need for any kind of resemblance of the symbol to the represented object. But, in visual representation, the resemblance of the represented object (the symbol) to the object (the denoted) is relevant. Unfortunately, the notion of resemblance is ambiguous. Any object has infinite “modes” that in VR become particularly relevant, for example, a shape, a behavior, a color, and a temperature. Therefore, the designer who creates the VR representation will make the decision based on the “mode” to adopt that best represents the object. Therefore, he or she predisposes the interpretation to be associated with the chosen symbolic representation. To clarify this point, let us consider perspective drawing: Perspective “catches a resemblance” or “renders the idea” (Panofsky 1927). But the ability to understand and decode perspective must be learned or acquired through experience. We are now very well trained in decoding perspective, since photography, television, and movies are all produced by a procedure, which is very much like the plane projection of perspective drawing. Photographic effects or artists’ creativity can modify and bend the geometric rules, for instance, by reducing the convergence effect in vertical lines (vertical borders of a building) or emphasizing the depth of field using optical illusions or using the “aerial perspective” of Leonardo da Vinci. This observation allows us to affirm that there is no mathematical rule to create a perspective representation that “catches the resemblance” even if the mathematics of projections is the basis of perspective computation in computer graphics. A perspective representation is therefore a figure that works like a description, and we are well trained in decoding and interpreting what can now be considered as perfectly natural. What is relevant is therefore not the mathematical accuracy of a perspective representation but its efficacy in conveying the denoted reality.

Besides denotation, in semiotics, it is important also to consider the concept of connotation, i.e., the set of values associated with the denoted object or the cultural and psychological aspects that are related to the object. While denotation solves the semantic problem by associating a sign to a meaning, so that it can become a symbol that can stand for the denoted object, connotation is related to the pragmatic aspect of a symbolic representation (Morris 1938).

When we look at a visual representation could we judge its realism by trying to answer a range of questions for example: what does it describe? What kind of description is it? To which extent does the representation need to resemble the represented object or, in other words, how similar should be the symbol to the denoted object? Does the similarity need to be so close that the symbol and the object are undistinguishable? This could give rise to an ambiguity that is perfectly illustrated by many Magritte’s paintings, among all the famous “Ceci n’est pas une pipe” (1929, LACMA Los Angeles County Museum of Art).

From the above discussion, the notion of resemblance is not the answer to the question what is realism. There are four other possible answers. First of all, there could be a probability that the represented object can be mistaken for the object—the illusion has been successful! But in a painting of an object it is almost impossible to mistake the represented object as in the example of the Magritte’s “pipe”. In VR, the question is more difficult, because we can understand that the purpose is to mistake the artificial world as a representation of a real object.

A second possible solution to the question on realism is the most realistic representation is the representation that has the largest amount of information. This is not an answer because we can just have two identical representations except for the color inversion, such as a negative and a positive photograph, and they have the same amount of information. To be more precise, in information theory, since the probability of observing a negative photograph is lower than that of a positive photograph, its information content should be larger, again contradicting this second possibility.

A third possibility is based on the notion of fidelity: the degree of exactness with which something is copied or reproduced. Consider again two pictures, negative and positive, they do not have the same level of fidelity, the positive is more faithful than the negative. Another way of considering this viewpoint is that the negative representation requires a key for decoding while the positive picture can be immediately decoded. We are accustomed to normal photographs, while in order to interpret negative photographs we require specific training. Another way of observing the criterion of fidelity can be derived from mathematical reasoning. The degree of realism of a representation of a real thing depends on a mapping between the representation and the object. As this mapping puts in a one-to-one correspondence each element of the representation to the elements of the real thing, the representation is closer to realism. Also, this answer is not satisfactory. First, it requires one to push the correspondence mapping to a possibly non-existing limit, for example reproducing all details at lower and lower geometric scale, and second, the designer of the representation performs an interpretation and a choice of what to represent, thus limiting the possibility of a complete mapping, referring back to a subjective answer. Moreover, the example of the positive and negative pictures is based on the same mapping function except for the color inversion so the problem is just moved up to the definition of the function.

Now, we arrive at the fourth answer. The realism depends on the easiness to interpret or decode the representation. It depends, therefore, on the stereotypes used in the representation that, in turn, depends on the custom, usage, and mode. In the end, realism can be considered as a style, as a particular kind of representation, and as a rhetorical choice. In our view, what is necessary is to create a VR representation that can be easily decoded, adopting the most appropriate style. This can be obtained by many means, even means that are very far from a strict correspondence between the real thing and its virtual replica. The association with stereotypes is moreover the connotative aspect of a symbolic representation, where cultural aspects are put to work to reach the understanding of the underlying semantics.

We can conclude that realism is a result of a rhetorical choice, a choice that aims at making believable a description or a representation. We must remember that rhetoric is an oratory art and its purpose is to persuade somebody using any means including emotions and organizing the discourse with cleverly designed arguments and logic. We are now deep in the discipline of communication, and in this context, we could ask how VR can be considered as a communication medium between users and the VR world and how multiple users, immersed in the VR environment, communicate with each other. To these two questions, the answer can be easy: human–computer interaction techniques and devices are the means of a communication process, they are the bidirectional channel from an information source to an information destination, be it another person or a computer program running behind the scene and controlling, for example, an intelligent avatar. In rhetoric art, the audience is addressed by leveraging logos, pathos, and ethos, i.e., the logic of the discourse, its ability to raise emotions, and its ethical and cultural coherence. All three aspects participate in communication, so the real fundamental questions are: how does VR influences communication? Has the communication process any impact on the perception of the realism of VR scenarios by the users? Are the emotions induced by VR modifying the way a user perceives the virtual situation with respect to the way she would perceive a real situation?

We will try to answer some of these questions by analyzing the structure of the VR communication using the metalanguage of semiotics that will allow us to characterize different VR solutions for different communication purposes. In 1992, (Maldonado 1992) proposed a study on VR semiotics, but since then no significant researches have been done to this aim.

In the context of rhetorical theory, the emotional results can be obtained using many forms of discourse, including metaphors, allegories, and figures. Following Lakoff (1993), we can consider a metaphor as a kind of mapping between two different conceptual domains, and the mapping should be: first, a one-to-one function, second, the two domains should exhibit the same behavior, to each action or rule in the first domain exists a corresponding action or rule in the second domain, so that anybody can forecast the evolution and project it from one domain to other. Lakoff considers metaphors as containers of a discourse, they are not only a linguistic construct, rather a conceptual construct, and more abstract a discourse is, more metaphoric levels are required to express the concepts. The classical rhetoric, in turn, tends to limit the role of metaphor as an argumentation tool and limits the scope of the metaphor to single names rather than concepts and frameworks.

When considering metaphors in VR communication, VR becomes a medium where a metaphor can be realized (see Lakoff 1993 p. 241). The correspondence between two domains related by the metaphor is critical. It is natural to try to solve this problem adopting methods derived from the physical and mathematical sciences (geometry, kinematics, dynamics, etc.). But this is not enough, we could have a very accurate numerical solution of a complex dynamical system or process but the conclusion is that the result of the accurate numerical simulation must be presented to a user with a visual interface. Unfortunately, Lakoff’s theory does not consider visual metaphors that, in classical rhetoric, are better named allegories. To this aim, we have tried to explore this problem with a semiotic approach.

The VR solution must take into account from the very beginning how to raise the desired emotions in the VR users, working on their perceptions of the virtual scenario, thus building up the conceptual framework in which the metaphor can live. We recall that metaphor is not the only rhetorical figure that can be used in VR simulation, and most important are figures that address in particular visual rhetoric, as exemplified by the above-mentioned Baroque feast and art.

VR as a communication process

This perspective of a VR application is not new, and it has been already considered as the creation of a fictional event (Laurel 1991; Hoorn et al. 2002). In a communication problem, we have different abstraction levels to consider, increasing from the lowest, syntactic level, followed by a semantic level and eventually the highest pragmatic level. It is the pragmatic level that deals with the purpose of the communication, in other words what is the desired outcome. Once the pragmatics of a communication process has been clarified, one can focus on what are the best technical solutions to reach the goal.

To better understand our approach, let us propose some simple example problems, deriving from our experience. A first example case is to explain to an operator how a complex equipment works—including the understanding of the process as well as of the necessary operations that need to be performed. A second example case is to allow a designer of an industrial plant to check the proposed solutions for the treatment of an emergency, like a fire or an explosion. It is without doubt that both problems can be addressed using a range of solutions, but both situations involve humans working in a highly emotional, dramatic environment. These cases derive from the research project VIRTHUALIS, whose aim was to evaluate human factors in risk assessment and evaluation during industrial processes. The major focus of this research was to adopt VR as a medium to perform otherwise impossible experiments: to test hypothesis and train technical people, during complex team works (Agadir and Marini 2010).

If we consider two examples as communication problems, we can gain a better insight into possible solutions. Going further with the first example, to understand the working of equipment with its underlying process, many aspects must be explained. A VR model of the equipment will be composed of various parts at different levels of detail: first the structure of the equipment, second the function of the equipment, and third the underlying model.

By the structure, we mean the organization into parts, the shape of the parts, the assembly of the parts, etc., what in general becomes the 3D geometric model of the equipment, possibly enriched with a dynamic behavior.

By the function of the equipment, we mean the way each part works, the way the assembly works, or, better say, how parts and assembly change as the time goes on or as an operator changes some part.

By the underlying model, we mean what are the physical, chemical, in general technical or scientific principles that rule the function of the equipment.

To better clarify, in the example considered, we are faced with an industrial plant (see Fig. 1) for chemical treatment of natural gas. The structure of the VR solution is, therefore, the 3D model of the plant, organized into parts following the function of the plant itself. Therefore, each plant component is modeled not with the purpose of obtaining a high visual realism, but with the purpose of allowing a technical user to interact with the plant component if it is needed for the purpose of the simulation. For example, the technical user can be asked to train himself to search for a gas leak, evaluate the leak amount, decide whether the whole plant has to be stopped or a maintenance action can be taken without stopping the plant, for instance isolating a plant section by closing a specific valve. But, to get a reliable and effective VR scenario, we also assume that a mathematical/chemical model of the gas processing is also available and running in a simulation context (the underlying model). The actions of the technical user can change parameters of the chemical process, thus forcing the simulation to compute the system’s evolution and provide change in other parameters, possibly to be communicated to the technical user, exposing him to the experience of, for example, an accident like a gas explosion. The above description of the possible use of the virtual world is exactly the result of a pragmatic analysis, driving to the choice of the communication purpose. It is this choice that leads the syntactic analysis and the implementation decisions.

Structure, function, and model constitute the syntactic level of the communication. They obey their specific internal rules and can be considered as specific languages. With syntactic constructs, we can build signs and symbols that have to be interpreted recognizing their semantics or meaning. To this aim, we must devise specific techniques of representation, i.e., how we represent to the operator the structure, the function, and the underlying model of the equipment. A good representation choice will be necessary to interpret the syntactic description of the virtual world, thus putting in play the semantic level of the communication process, which includes also rhetoric and styles choices. Having chosen VR as the fundamental medium, the representation is based first on visual or pictorial representation. But differently from static pictures, drawings, or photographs, VR visual representation allows dynamics to come into play, i.e., how the represented system evolves following the internal model or the user interaction that changes parameters. For example, static drawings can help to describe the assembly of a complex equipment using for example the so-called exploded view, while a dynamic representation of the same assembly can show how each part is connected to all others and in which order, using, e.g., computer animation techniques. Besides dynamic representation, VR allows us also to overcome another limit of static drawings: the interaction of the operator with the representation of the equipment and its parts. Interactivity allows us to explore the function of the equipment in deeper detail, observe and experiment with the virtual equipment and therefore understand also the underlying model of the equipment. Instead of simply reading the description of complex equipment and observe a static illustration of its structure, using VR one can perform interactively an experiment by manipulating the equipment’s parts or parameters and by observing what happens as they are changed.

A similar description can be developed for the second example case: to check a design of a plant for assessing risk. Here, again we need to represent the structure of the plant, its functions, and eventually the underlying model. The details to which different elements of the plant will be represented and described to the designer depend on the specific aim: if the designer is a chemical engineer, the presence of the underlying model should be must to check the coherence of the construction with the purpose, while if the designer is a construction engineer his major interest could be the structure of the plant, its layout, considering the risk aspects related to the “topographical” distribution of the plant components or the efficiency of the layout for assembly and maintenance purposes.

In the above discussion, it is clear how the pragmatic aspect of communication comes into play. The pragmatic emerges when we consider the role and the competencies of the designer, the user or the operator, finalizing the representation to their needs. At this stage, a fundamental role is played also by the emotional state of the user, that is how the user perceives the environment, what he/she feels real and how the VR alters its perceptive and emotional states. The communication process realizes the top level because the user, immersed in the VR, begins to believe in a different perception and a different reality, not necessary similar to the real world’s one. In the last example above, the pragmatic aspect that comes into play is the purpose of the designer, e.g., to check the assembly process or to check a maintenance operation.

When we design a VR application, we can adopt the metaphor of the theater (Laurel 1991): we need to put on stage a kind of interactive play, trying to know who are the interested users, what are their expectations, background knowledge, and what is the desired outcome of the drama.

Human–VR interaction

The possibility of interaction introduces a specific character to VR as communication. In a way, interaction is also one of the means allowing communication to happen. Differently from static visual representations, in VR, we have the advantage of the possibility of dynamic representation, where the evolution of a process can be described by moving images and by animating objects. Also, a complex structure can be deeply explored by navigating interactively inside it. Therefore, the function of a complex system or process can be considered as: (a) observing the autonomous evolution of the system or (b) doing some action on the system to change its status and making it start to carry out its function or change the direction of its evolution.

The autonomous evolution of the system (case a) can be a mathematical function of some time-dependent model, being the time an independent variable, it can flow in full correspondence with real time (a second time unit lasts exactly for a second) or it can be expanded or compressed to allow a user to observe a very fast or a very slow process. The choice between real time and artificial time corresponds, as said earlier, to a rhetoric choice, so it must be kept coherent to the pragmatic purpose of the communication, allowing us to drive the user attention to some relevant aspects of the evolution of the process.

To implement dynamic evolution that depends from a user action (case b), we are moved to the problem of interaction management, keeping the solution coherent with the chosen style of graphics representation, and also to the rhetoric style that has been selected.

It is important that in designing the interaction in a VR system, structure and interaction are represented in a coherent way. This does not mean that the same style of graphics representation should be used for the representation of the structure and of the interaction, but that different interaction tasks on the structure should use appropriate level of abstraction coherent with the style of interacting. This is particularly true for the direct manipulation, with this interaction style, VR offers a variety of devices that are more or less suited to the graphics style chosen for the representation.

In general, interaction is very demanding in terms of user understanding and requires training. The concept of affordance, proposed by Gibson (1979) and further developed by Norman (1988), is the most effective concept to guide the implementation of interaction. This concept is particularly interesting when the interaction in VR aims at mimicking the interaction with everyday objects. It is usual that an interactive system interface is based on a specific metaphor that simplifies user interpretation of the meaning of possible commands, possible states of the system, etc. The interface of a VR program, which is the medium used to perform interaction with a virtual world, should therefore be coherent within the framework of the simulated world. The above-mentioned techniques and basic tools will be exploited putting them in an environment, which will adopt the necessary graphics style and the necessary rhetoric effects to build up the cognitive context where the metaphor can be interpreted.

It is also worthwhile to recall that other devices can improve the level of interaction, giving both to the virtual and real world some level of knowledge or intelligence, by means, e.g., some kind of phidget.

In the experimental case described in the previous paragraph, we had the problem of implementing the user interaction with a gas detector device and, in the same time, we had the problem of providing the user with a navigation device, to explore the plant, moving around, climbing up further levels in the 3D scenario. To solve both problems, we have adopted a very well-known device, the WiiMote© by Nintendo. From one side, it provided the affordance of the real gas detector (see Fig. 2); on the other side, it also provided easy solution to navigate and interact with other plant components, without requiring a long training to the user.

A different choice could have been to adopt a game console joystick; the drawback of such solution is that the technical user would be invited to consider the simulation a kind of video game, thus changing radically the selected metaphor. Moreover, such device would have required a difficult training to simulate the action of a handheld probe. See Fig. 3.

The pragmatic level

In the theory of communication, pragmatics is the discipline that explores the relationship between signs and their meaning in relationships to values and culture of persons. Each person has his or her experience, and during a communication, each participant has his or her context, beliefs, knowledge, emotions, and affections. In human communication, each act can be an assertion, an imperative command, a desire; normally in speech communication, intonation or non-verbal communication (expression of the face, gesture, etc.) contribute to convey the characteristic of the communication act.

In VR, communication is between a person and a computer system, where non-verbal communication is almost absent, and there is no exchange of experience between two human participants in a traditional communication. VR can also be used as the communication medium between two or more human beings; in this case, it is necessary to provide clues for transmitting non-verbal information among participants. The use of avatars can be a solution to provide a richer communication of a single user with a computer system, in the case where the VR application would require the presence of virtual actors.

To supply to this lack of information, a VR communication must use other means, like the richness of information conveyed by the visual and non-visual sensing or by the interactivity.

It is by means of interactivity that we can influence the pragmatic level. Depending on the possible actions, different roles can be played by different actors, like e.g., limiting interaction to navigation or extending it to the possibility of changing the status of the underlying model evolution. It is evident that these two different interaction levels can generate different emotional statuses: curiosity in navigation versus anxiety in status change. If the status change can put the simulated system in an unstable status, the user can become anxious about possible outcome of the non-stability, like, in an industrial plant, the possibility of an accident.

In our experiments on using VR simulation for industrial training, we involved two kinds of technical users: a user working on the virtual plant in search of a gas leak and a second user working remotely in a non-immersive environment that simply simulated a control room and control panel of the plant section. The two users could play a simulation mimicking a real situation, where the control room operator communicates via radio with the field operator and both exchange their information and observations reaching a shared view on the decision to stop or not the whole plant to cope with the gas leak. The experiments have demonstrated that the status of anxiety of both operators (analyzed with postexperiment interviews by a psychologist) was very close to the status of anxiety of a real situation, even if the degree of realism of the control room simulation was very low with respect to that of the 3D plant model.

The experience gained testing this case study is a confirmation of many observations. The degree of realism is not due to the technical level of visual accuracy, is not due to the accuracy of the dynamical simulation of the underlying process, it is mainly due to how believable or verisimile is the situation where the technical operators are immersed, in other words how the story that we have planned for their performance is close to a real possible story, how it has been put on stage, and how the surrounding environment is coherent with the story itself.

Conclusions

We have discussed in which sense a VR simulation can be considered as a communication process and its design as a communication problem. From this viewpoint, we have clarified the notion of realism and its importance to create immersive and believable simulations. Considering VR design as a communication problem moreover makes it possible to implement a solution following clear principle, orchestrating every element of the VR world in a coherent way. The syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic character of a VR application can be analyzed, and it is possible to determine the technical solutions that better implement the desired communication, determining whether a simple desktop, a large theater screen, or a head-mounted display should be adopted. Interaction will be implemented on the basis of the specific objectives, adopting, if necessary, haptic devices, audio signals, etc.

Our approach can provide guidelines for the detailed design of a VR solution to a given problem.

Being VR interaction a communication process, the developers must be conscious of the criticality of how communication is implemented, selecting the appropriate level of detail and accuracy in visualization, interaction and modeling, selecting the appropriate sensory stimulation systems, and determining the necessary languages to be proposed to perform human–VR interaction.
